name: Magnetic Field Generators:promo
economy: Cost 22+3=25 MC (steel payable). Value: 2 plant-prod (16) + 3 TR (22.2) + tile = 38+. But -4 energy-prod is huge (-30). Net ~8 MC value. Building tag helps.
reasoning: The massive energy cost of -4 makes this extremely situational. You need heavy energy surplus to even consider it. The TR + plant-prod package is solid but the energy requirement locks it into late-game niche plays. Building tag and steel-payable help slightly.
when_to_pick: Only when you have 5+ energy production with no better use for it. Late-game steel dump with excess energy.

name: Magnetic Shield
economy: Cost 24+3=27 MC (ti payable). Value: 4 TR = ~29.6 MC. Net ~+3 MC. Space tag worth 1-2 MC. Requirement: 3 Power tags is steep.
reasoning: Good value on paper -- 4 TR for 27 MC is solid, especially titanium-payable. But 3 Power tags is a difficult requirement that limits when this can be played. Per COTD experts, it's a fine VP dump card but you can't rely on meeting the requirements. Niche but decent when it works.
when_to_pick: When you already have 2 power tags and titanium to spend. Late-game titanium dump when requirements are met.

name: Mangrove
economy: Cost 12+3=15 MC. Value: 1 greenery (TR if O2 not maxed = 7-7.4) + 1 VP (5) + placement bonus (2-4) + Plant tag (1-2). Total ~15-19 MC. Great efficiency.
reasoning: One of the best VP cards in the game. Cheap greenery on ocean space with 1 VP printed. If oxygen isn't maxed, you get TR + VP + placement bonuses for very little. The 4C requirement is easy to meet. COTD experts universally praise it. Plant tag adds value for NRA/Insects synergy.
when_to_pick: Almost always draft if offered. Best in mid-to-late game but worth speculating on early. Even without O2 raise, 1 VP + greenery for 15 MC is solid.

name: Market Manipulation
economy: Cost 1+3=4 MC. Value: +1 colony track step (~2-3 MC) + deny opponent ~2-3 MC. Net roughly break-even. Earth tag worth 2-3 MC. Event tag for Legend.
reasoning: Low impact but cheap. The Earth+Event tag combo enables rebates (Media Group +3, IC +2, Point Luna card). Without rebates it's marginally worth playing; with rebates it becomes decent. Krazyguy75 argues it's too low-impact; benbever says it's almost always good. In 3P it's solidly mediocre.
when_to_pick: When you have event/Earth tag rebates. Low draft priority otherwise. Good as a free draw.

name: Mars Nomads
economy: Cost 13+3=16 MC. No tags (penalty -3 to -5). Action: collect placement bonuses (~2-6 MC/use). Over 4-5 uses = 8-30 MC total value. High variance.
reasoning: Strong action card that collects placement bonuses repeatedly. In 3P harder to block than 2P but still very good if played early. The no-tag penalty hurts (-3 to -5). FieldMouse007 calls it strong; community consensus is it's great early, weak late. Map-dependent value with Elysium being best.
when_to_pick: Early game only. If drawn gen 3+ the value drops significantly. Best on maps with rich placement bonuses (Elysium).

name: Mars University
economy: Cost 8+3=11 MC (steel payable). Value: 1 VP (5) + Science tag (3-5) + Building tag (1-2) + card cycling (~2 MC per science tag played). After 3-4 science tags = 6-8 MC from cycling.
reasoning: One of the best cards in the game. Cheap, no requirements, incredible tags (Science+Building), 1 VP, and the card cycling effect is a true engine enabler. COTD experts nearly unanimously rate it top 5. The ability to swap bad cards for new ones compounds over the game. Even ad_hocNC, who is skeptical of engines, acknowledges its potency.
when_to_pick: Always. First-pick caliber in most drafts. Play as early as possible to maximize cycling value.

name: Martian Media Center
economy: Cost 7+3=10 MC (steel payable). Value: 2 MC-prod (10-12) + action saves 2 MC/gen on delegates. Building tag (1-2). Over 4 gens, action saves 8 MC.
reasoning: Excellent value when Mars First is accessible. The 2 MC-prod alone nearly pays for the card, and the cheap delegate action (3 MC instead of 5) adds up significantly. Building tag is good. The party requirement is manageable in 3P since Mars First is popular. benbever rates it highly.
when_to_pick: When Mars First is ruling or you have 2 delegates there. Best early game for maximum production value.

name: Martian Rails
economy: Cost 13+3=16 MC. Action: spend 1 energy for X MC (X = cities on Mars). At 3 cities = 3 MC/action. Break-even at ~6 cities = gen 5+ typically. Energy cost = ~2 MC.
reasoning: Too expensive, too slow. In 3P games, experienced players don't build many cities, so this rarely reaches 4-5 MC/action. The energy cost is real. COTD experts (shai_aus, ad_hocNC, Krazyguy75) all rate it poorly. It breaks even at 6 cities which rarely happens early enough to matter.
when_to_pick: Almost never. Only if the table is city-heavy and you have excess energy. Even then there are better options.

name: Martian Survey
economy: Cost 9+3=12 MC. Value: 2 cards (6-8) + 1 VP (5) + Science tag (3-5). Total ~14-18 MC. Decent but max 4% O2 limits timing.
reasoning: Overpriced for what it does without discounts. 12 MC for 2 blind draws + 1 VP is mediocre early game when you'd rather have production. The max 4% O2 requirement means it can only be played early. With rebates (IC, Media Group, Valley Trust) it becomes much better. Science+Event tags enable combos.
when_to_pick: When you have event/science rebates. Also good for Legend milestone. Don't speculate on it if O2 might spike early.

name: Martian Zoo
economy: Cost 12+3=15 MC. Value: 1 VP (5) + Animal+Building tags (3) + action ~2 MC/Earth tag played. With 4-5 Earth tags post-play = 8-10 MC from action.
reasoning: Strong when played early with many Earth tags incoming. The 2-city requirement can delay it significantly in 3P. Animal+Building is a great tag combo for Ecologist/Diversifier. With Meat Industry combo it becomes powerful. But inconsistent -- sometimes cities don't appear until mid-game.
when_to_pick: When 2 cities exist and you plan to play Earth tags. Best with city preludes or Tharsis in game.

name: Mass Converter
economy: Cost 8+3=11 MC. Value: 6 energy-prod (45 MC!) + space discount effect. But 5 Science tags is a very steep requirement. Science+Power tags (~4+1).
reasoning: Absurdly efficient IF you can meet the 5 Science tag requirement. The cheapest energy source in the game by far. Krazyguy75 says it's undervalued by 24 cost. But the requirement makes it unplayable in many games. In science-heavy engines it's a game-changer. Score reflects requirement difficulty balancing raw power.
when_to_pick: When you already have 3+ science tags and plan to play more. Keep in hand speculatively if drawn early with science path.

name: Maxwell Base
economy: Cost 18+3=21 MC + 1 energy-prod (~7.5). Value: 3 VP (15) + City+Venus tags (3) + action (free floater/animal). Total ~18+action. Net slightly negative without synergy.
reasoning: The 3 VP is decent but expensive. The action becomes strong with Stratospheric Birds (free VP per gen). Without a floater/animal target, it's an overpriced VP card. The 12% Venus requirement and energy cost limit when it can be played. icehawk84 notes it scores heavily with the right target.
when_to_pick: When you have a 1VP animal/floater card to feed. Late-game 3 VP dump if Venus is high. Strong with Strat Birds combo.

name: Meat Industry
economy: Cost 5+3=8 MC (steel payable). Value: Building tag (1-2) + 2 MC per animal gained. With 1 animal/gen = Sponsors equivalent. With 2+/gen = absurd value.
reasoning: Cheap enabler that scales from mediocre to broken. With Ecological Zone, Martian Zoo, Pets, or Miranda colony, it generates massive MC. Floor is low (need animal cards), but ceiling is extraordinary. Krazyguy75 notes it's 'never fine -- always either too strong or too weak.' Draft it when you have animal synergy.
when_to_pick: When you have 1+ VP animal cards or Ecological Zone. With Miranda colony in play it becomes very strong. Don't draft without animal synergy.

name: Media Archives
economy: Cost 8+3=11 MC. Value: 1 MC per event ever played. In 3P by late game ~12-18 events = 12-18 MC. Net +1-7 MC. Earth tag (2-3).
reasoning: Late-game money bomb that's hard to time well. In 3P, events accumulate reasonably but you can't play this early (not enough events). icehawk84 says it's almost always strong late in 3P+. The Earth tag adds value. But it occupies hand space while providing zero value until played. Inferior to Investment Loan in flexibility.
when_to_pick: Mid-to-late game when ~15+ events have been played. Don't speculate on it early unless cash is abundant.

name: Media Group
economy: Cost 6+3=9 MC. Value: Earth tag (2-3) + 3 MC per event played. Breaks even at 3 events. After 5 events = +6 MC profit.
reasoning: Excellent rebate card. Events are generally strong cards you want to play anyway, so this adds pure value. Breaks even after just 3 events, which is very achievable. shai_aus calls it great, especially early. ad_hocNC rates it solid B-tier. Earth tag adds synergy with Point Luna, Teractor, etc.
when_to_pick: Early game with events in hand. Even mid-game it's good if you expect 3+ more events. High draft priority.

name: Medical Lab
economy: Cost 13+3=16 MC (steel payable). Value: 1 VP (5) + Science+Building tags (4-7) + 1 MC-prod per 2 building tags. At 4 buildings = 2 MC-prod (10-12). Total ~19-24.
reasoning: Situationally good but requires many building tags to be efficient. In all-expansion play, building tag density is lower than base game. Krazyguy75 notes expansions hurt this card. The Science+Building tag combo is excellent for milestones/awards. Best with Mining Guild or steel-heavy strategies.
when_to_pick: When you have 4+ building tags and can pay with steel. Good late-game steel dump for VP + science tag.

name: Meltworks
economy: Cost 4+3=7 MC (steel payable). Action: 5 heat (6 MC) -> 3 steel (6 MC). Net 0 per action. Building tag (1-2). Need heat surplus with steel targets.
reasoning: Very niche heat-to-steel converter that barely breaks even on the action. The 7 MC upfront cost means you need several uses just to recover investment. Only worthwhile with Advanced Alloys/Rego Plastics (3 steel = 9-12 MC). shai_aus and most COTD experts find it too situational. Building tag is the main appeal.
when_to_pick: Only with Advanced Alloys AND heat surplus AND steel targets. Or as a cheap building tag for Builder milestone.

name: Mercurian Alloys
economy: Cost 3+3=6 MC (ti payable). Value: Space tag (1-2) + titanium worth +1 each. With 6 titanium used = 6 MC extra value. With 12+ titanium = 12+ MC.
reasoning: Extremely cheap for a powerful ongoing effect. 2 Science tags is a manageable requirement. Makes every titanium resource worth 25% more. Scales beautifully with Phobolog, titanium production, and ti-heavy strategies. benbever provides detailed analysis showing excellent synergies with ti-production preludes.
when_to_pick: When you have 2+ science tags and titanium production/resources. Cheap space tag for milestones too.

name: Methane From Titan
economy: Cost 28+3=31 MC (ti payable). Value: 2 heat-prod (8) + 2 plant-prod (16) + 2 VP (10) + Jovian+Space tags (4-7). Total ~38-41 MC. But anti-synergy: heat/plants want rush, Jovian wants engine.
reasoning: Good value on paper but internally conflicted. Plant+heat production wants early game rush; Jovian tag + VP want long engine games. Futuralis's top comment (30 upvotes) nails this anti-synergy. Best played gen 1-2 with Inventrix or Smelting Plant prelude, but the 2% O2 req often prevents that. Overpriced for late game.
when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 when O2 is already 2%+ and you have titanium. Don't draft for Jovian tag alone -- too expensive.

name: Micro-Mills
economy: Cost 3+3=6 MC. Value: 1 heat-prod (4 MC). No tags = penalty (-3 to -5). Net: -5 to -7 MC. Only worth it to reach heat thresholds.
reasoning: Overpriced for what it does. No tags is a severe penalty. 6 MC for 1 heat production is barely break-even in gen 1 and bad any later. ad_hocNC notes it has some value for reaching 4 or 8 heat thresholds. COTD consensus is low/zero draft priority. The boring card meme is earned.
when_to_pick: Almost never in draft. Play if drawn free and it gets your heat production to a multiple of 8. Generalist milestone edge case.

name: Microgravity Nutrition
economy: Cost 11+3=14 MC. Value: 1 VP (5) + Microbe+Plant tags (3-4) + 1 MC-prod per colony. At 2 colonies = 10 MC-prod; at 3 = 15. Total ~18-24 with 2-3 colonies.
reasoning: Requires multiple colonies early to be worthwhile, which is uncommon in 3P. The Microbe+Plant double bio-tag is decent for milestones but the effect is weak. FieldMouse007 calls it mediocre. At 2 colonies it's barely break-even considering gen played. Niche card that rarely excites.
when_to_pick: Only with 3+ colonies already placed early game. The double bio-tag is the main appeal for specific milestones.

name: Mine
economy: Cost 4+3=7 MC (steel payable). Value: 1 steel-prod (8 MC) + Building tag (1-2). Total ~9-10 MC. Net +2-3 MC gen 1.
reasoning: Simple, solid production card. 7 MC for 1 steel production is good value early. Building tag helps with Builder milestone. icehawk84 rates it a keep in opening hand and high priority gen 1-2. It becomes useless mid-game though. Not exciting but reliably decent when played early.
when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 when you have steel targets. Cheap building tag filler. Skip after gen 3.

name: Mineral Deposit
economy: Cost 5+3=8 MC. Value: 5 steel (10 MC). Net +2 MC. No tags = penalty (-3 to -5). Event for Legend. Better with rebates.
reasoning: Small but positive value if you can spend the steel. The no-tag penalty hurts significantly. With IC/Media Group rebates it becomes good. benbever notes it's good for Legend milestone and Miner award. Low impact but rarely bad. Not worth a high draft pick.
when_to_pick: When you have event rebates or need steel for specific plays. Low draft priority. Good as free draw.

name: Mining Area
economy: Cost 4+3=7 MC (steel payable). Value: 1 steel/ti-prod (8-12.5) + placement bonus (2-3) + Building tag (1-2). Total ~11-17 MC. Net +4-10 MC.
reasoning: One of the best production cards when placement is available. Requires a tile next to your own on a mineral spot, which limits early-game use. On titanium it's phenomenal (12.5 MC value for 7 MC cost). shai_aus rates it S-tier for Mining Guild. The tile placement is bonus value for milestones/awards.
when_to_pick: When you have a tile adjacent to a mineral spot. Prioritize titanium over steel. Keep in opening hand.

name: Mining Expedition
economy: Cost 12+3=15 MC. Value: 1 O2 TR (7-7.4) + 2 steel (4 MC) - take-that penalty (5-10 in 3P). Net ~-4 to +1 MC. No tags = penalty.
reasoning: The 2 plant removal is take-that which hurts in 3P (helps the 3rd player for free). The no-tag penalty compounds the issue. The O2 raise is useful for snatching the 8% temperature bonus or enabling requirements. 2 steel is a small consolation. Niche applications exist but generally mediocre.
when_to_pick: To snatch O2 bonuses or end the game. Take-that in 3P is a real downside. Low priority in draft.

name: Mining Quota
economy: Cost 5+3=8 MC (steel payable). Value: 2 steel-prod (16 MC gen 1) + Building tag (1-2). Total ~17-18 MC. Net +9-10 MC gen 1. But req: Venus+Earth+Jovian tags.
reasoning: Incredible value IF requirements are met -- 2 steel production for 8 MC is absurd efficiency. The triple planetary tag requirement (Venus+Earth+Jovian) is the real challenge. With preludes and wild tags it's occasionally achievable gen 1. icehawk84 calls it insane value when played early. FieldMouse007 notes sometimes you pass because unlocking requirements is too costly.
when_to_pick: When you naturally have or can cheaply get all three planetary tags. Don't bend your strategy to meet the req.

name: Mining Rights
economy: Cost 9+3=12 MC (steel payable). Value: 1 steel/ti-prod (8-12.5) + placement bonus (2-5) + Building tag (1-2). Total ~11-20 MC. Net -1 to +8 MC.
reasoning: Similar to Mining Area but doesn't require adjacency to your own tile -- just placement on a mineral spot. This gives flexibility and 'teleportation' value for spreading across the map. On titanium spots it's good value. shai_aus rates it great for Mining Guild, ok for others. The 5 MC premium over Mining Area is the teleport flexibility.
when_to_pick: Gen 1-3 on a titanium spot. Decent for teleporting across the map. Less valuable after gen 3.

name: Minority Refuge
economy: Cost 5+3=8 MC + 2 MC-prod lost (10). Total effective ~18 MC for a colony (SP costs 17). Space tag (1-2). Late game: -2 prod irrelevant.
reasoning: Early game it's slightly worse than SP colony due to MC-prod loss. But it's titanium-payable via Space tag and gets better late-game when the -2 MC-prod doesn't matter. Good for grabbing placement bonuses (Europa ocean, Miranda animal) cheaply in final gens. benbever provides detailed analysis of niche scenarios.
when_to_pick: Late game for colony placement bonuses when -2 MC-prod is irrelevant. Early game only if securing a critical colony spot.

name: Miranda Resort
economy: Cost 12+3=15 MC (ti payable). Value: 1 VP (5) + Jovian+Space tags (4-7) + MC-prod per Earth tag. At 3 Earth tags = 15 MC-prod. Total ~24-27 with 3 tags.
reasoning: Decent MC production if you have 3+ Earth tags, plus Jovian tag for multipliers. But doesn't include its own Earth tag (unlike Cartels), making it strictly worse for economy. The Jovian tag adds value for multipliers and milestones. shai_aus rates Cartels higher. Best for Point Luna/Teractor with many Earth tags.
when_to_pick: When you have 3+ Earth tags for MC-prod, or need a cheap Jovian tag. Ti-payable helps late game.

name: Mohole Area
economy: Cost 20+3=23 MC (steel payable). Value: 4 heat-prod (16 MC gen 1, but ~24 in quantified) + tile on ocean space + Building tag. Total ~26-30 MC. Net +3-7.
reasoning: Best heat production card in the game. 4 heat-prod for 20 MC steel-payable is excellent. The tile on ocean space gives placement bonuses and map control. shai_aus, ad_hocNC, and icehawk84 all rate it highly. Great for Robotic Workforce copy. Enables 1 temperature raise every 2 gens. Must play gen 1-2 for full value.
when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 as terraforming anchor. Steel payable makes it very efficient. Late game it's too slow.

name: Mohole Lake
economy: Cost 31+3=34 MC (steel payable). Value: 1 temp TR (10) + 1 ocean (14) + 3 plants (7.5) + action (microbe or animal). Total ~31.5 + action. Slightly negative base.
reasoning: Big, expensive card that does many things but none amazingly. The terraforming value roughly equals cost. The action is nice with GHG Bacteria or 1VP animals but requires additional cards. Steel-payable is a big plus. COTD consensus: it's okay but conflicted between terraforming and engine. Best as a steel dump with a microbe/animal target.
when_to_pick: With excess steel AND a microbe/animal target for the action. Don't play just for the terraforming.

name: Molecular Printing
economy: Cost 11+3=14 MC. Value: 1 VP (5) + Science tag (3-5) + 1 MC per city and colony in play. In 3P late game: ~8-12 cities+colonies = 8-12 MC. Net ~2-8 MC.
reasoning: Player-count and timing dependent. In 3P with colonies, late game could see 8-12 combined cities+colonies. The science tag and 1 VP are always useful. Krazyguy75 rates it balanced to bonkers depending on context. FieldMouse007 calls it mediocre. In 3P all-expansions it's solidly average -- a free VP+science tag with some MC back.
when_to_pick: Late game when colonies and cities have accumulated. The science tag may enable other plays.

name: Moss
economy: Cost 4+3=7 MC - 1 plant (~2). Value: 1 plant-prod (8 MC) + Plant tag (1-2). Total ~9-10 MC. Net ~0-3 MC accounting for plant loss.
reasoning: Simple, cheap plant production with a useful Plant tag. The 3 ocean requirement is easy to meet by gen 2-3. Losing 1 plant is minor. shai_aus calls it perfectly fine mid-tier. The Plant tag is valuable for NRA/Insects. Not exciting but functional. Better as part of a plant engine than standalone.
when_to_pick: Gen 2-4 when 3 oceans are out and you want plant production or a cheap plant tag.

name: Natural Preserve
economy: Cost 9+3=12 MC (steel payable). Value: 1 VP (5) + 1 MC-prod (5-6) + Science+Building tags (4-7) + tile placement (teleport, 2-4 bonus). Total ~16-22 MC. Net +4-10.
reasoning: Underrated card with excellent tags (Science+Building), a tile for teleporting, VP, and some MC production. Max 4% O2 limits it to early game but that's when you want production anyway. icehawk84 rates it often a high priority. The tile placement on Elysium can grab the 3-card spot. Steel payable is nice.
when_to_pick: Gen 1-2 when O2 is low. Excellent early for science tag, tile placement, and production. Dead card after 4% O2.

name: Neutralizer Factory
economy: Cost 7+3=10 MC. Value: 1 Venus TR (7-7.4) + Venus tag (2-3). Total ~9-10 MC. Net ~-1 to 0 MC. Req: 10% Venus.
reasoning: 10 MC for 1 TR is mediocre, and the 10% Venus requirement means you can't play it until mid-game. The Venus tag has some value for Venuphile award. benbever notes it rarely sees play. Most COTD comments are dismissive. It's not terrible but there's almost always something better to spend MC on.
when_to_pick: Only when Venus is near 14-16% and you want the bonus TR from reaching the threshold. Very low priority.

name: New Holland
economy: Cost 20+3=23 MC (steel payable). Value: 3 MC-prod (15-18) + City (placement VP) + City+Building tags (2-3). Req: 4 cities on Mars. Net ~-5 to -2.
reasoning: Interesting concept but 4 cities on Mars requirement is very difficult to meet in 3P before good spots are gone. No COTD data available. The 3 MC-prod is decent and it's steel payable. Placing a city on an ocean tile is unique but the requirement severely limits playability. Niche promo card.
when_to_pick: Only when 4+ cities exist on Mars AND good ocean spots remain for city placement. Very rare scenario.

name: Nitrite Reducing Bacteria
economy: Cost 11+3=14 MC. Value: starts with 3 microbes. Action: +1 microbe or spend 3 microbes for 1 TR (7-7.4). First TR immediate. Then 1 TR per 3 actions = ~2.3 MC/action. Microbe tag (1-2).
reasoning: Too slow and expensive. 14 MC upfront for something that generates 1 TR immediately then 1 TR every 3 actions. shai_aus repeatedly rates it poorly across multiple COTD threads. ad_hocNC calls it bad and a trap for UNMI. The TR doesn't end the game faster (Venus-like). Only useful with microbe colony/external microbe sources.
when_to_pick: Almost never. Only with multiple microbe-adding sources that make it produce TR faster.

name: Nitrogen from Titan
economy: Cost 25+3=28 MC (ti payable). Value: 2 TR (14.8) + 1 VP (5) + 2 floaters (~3) + Jovian+Space tags (4-7). Total ~27-30 MC. Break-even with tags.
reasoning: A typical 'yet another Jovian' card. In isolation it's mediocre, but with multipliers and ti-discounts it becomes decent. The floaters on a Jovian card can add value (Jovian Lanterns for +1 VP). Krazyguy75 says at best it's good, never bad. Requires synergy to shine. Ti-payable helps in late game.
when_to_pick: Late game with Jovian multipliers and titanium to spend. Low priority without specific synergy.

name: Nitrogen-Rich Asteroid
economy: Cost 31+3=34 MC (ti payable). Without 3 plant tags: 2 TR (14.8) + 1 temp (10) + 1 plant-prod (8). Total ~33. With 3 plant tags: +4 plant-prod instead = 32 MC plant-prod. Total ~57 MC.
reasoning: One of the most powerful cards in the game when played with 3 plant tags. 4 plant production + 3 TR is game-winning if played gen 1-3. shai_aus's sarcastic 'absolutely terrible' comment (42 upvotes) reveals community consensus that this is S-tier. Even without 3 plant tags it's decent. With Ecoline/NRA enablers, it dominates. The Space tag makes it ti-payable.
when_to_pick: Always draft. With 2+ plant tags, start planning to meet the 3-tag threshold. Without plant tags, still decent for TR+temp+plant-prod.

name: Nitrophilic Moss
economy: Cost 8+3=11 MC - 2 plants (~4). Value: 2 plant-prod (16 MC gen 1). Net ~+1 to +5 MC. Plant tag (1-2). Req: 3 oceans + 2 plants.
reasoning: Good plant production card -- basically Algae at 2 MC less with easier requirement (3 oceans vs 5). The 2 plant cost is manageable. icehawk84 calls it underrated and the best of the mosses. Plant tag is useful for NRA/Insects/Ecologist. Not flashy but solid when played early-mid game.
when_to_pick: Gen 2-4 when 3 oceans are out and you have 2+ plants. Good plant tag for NRA/Insects synergy.

name: Noctis City
economy: Cost 18+3=21 MC (steel payable) + 1 energy-prod (~7.5). Value: 3 MC-prod (15-18) + city (1-3 VP from greeneries) + City+Building tags (2-3). On Tharsis: +3-4 VP from greeneries.
reasoning: Map-dependent value. On Tharsis it's strong -- the reserved area often has great adjacency for greeneries and the 'surprise city' play catches opponents. icehawk84 rates it very strong on Tharsis, not great elsewhere. The -1 energy-prod cost is annoying early but irrelevant last gen. shai_aus likes it as a late-game play on Tharsis.
when_to_pick: On Tharsis: high priority, buy early and play late for surprise city. On other maps: mediocre, only with excess steel.

name: Nuclear Power
economy: Cost 10+3=13 MC (steel payable) + 2 MC-prod lost (10). Total ~23 MC gen 1. Value: 3 energy-prod (22.5). Net ~-0.5 MC gen 1, better mid-game.
reasoning: Good when you need lots of energy (colonies trading, oxygen bumpers, Physics Complex). The -2 MC-prod hurts early but matters less mid-late game. benbever notes mid-game effective cost is only ~19 MC for 3 energy. Power+Building tags are useful. Preferred: Peroxide Power for smaller needs.
when_to_pick: When you specifically need 3 energy production. With colonies it's good in opening hand. Without specific energy needs, skip.

name: Nuclear Zone
economy: Cost 10+3=13 MC. Value: 2 temp (2 TR = 14.8) + placement bonus (2-6) + Earth tag (2-3) + tile teleport (variable). Minus 2 VP (= -10). Net: ~9-14 MC.
reasoning: Extremely efficient temperature raise. shai_aus (34 upvotes) and icehawk84 (21 upvotes) both rate it highly. The -2 VP is offset by the 2 TR, making it roughly VP-neutral while giving income, placement bonus, teleport tile, and an Earth tag. Great for game control -- ending the game when ahead, snatching temp bonuses. ad_hocNC calls it his favourite card.
when_to_pick: Almost always draft. Excellent for terraformers, good tile teleport for anyone. Even engine players can use it to deny opponents.

name: Olympus Conference
economy: Cost 10+3=13 MC (steel payable). Value: 1 VP (5) + Science+Earth+Building tags (6-10) + free card every 2 science tags. After 4 science tags = 2 free cards (6-8 MC).
reasoning: Incredible triple-tag card with card draw engine. Not quite Mars University (which swaps every science tag vs every other), but the Earth+Building+Science tags make it arguably better in some dimensions. shai_aus gives it 30 upvotes calling it amazing. Steel-payable, no requirements, 1 VP. One of the best engine cards in the game.
when_to_pick: Always. High first-pick priority. Play early to maximize card draw. The triple-tag is unmatched.

name: Omnicourt
economy: Cost 11+3=14 MC (steel payable). Value: 2 TR (14.8) + Building tag (1-2). Total ~16 MC. Net ~+2 MC. Req: Venus+Earth+Jovian tags.
reasoning: 2 TR for 14 MC steel-payable is decent. The triple planetary tag requirement limits when you can play it. icehawk84 rates it what Release of Inert Gases should have been. FieldMouse007 calls it mediocre. As a steel dump with tags already met, it's fine. Not worth bending strategy for.
when_to_pick: When you naturally have Venus+Earth+Jovian tags and excess steel. Late-game steel dump for TR.

name: Optimal Aerobraking
economy: Cost 7+3=10 MC. Value: Space tag (1-2) + 3 MC + 3 heat (~3.6 MC) per space event = ~6.6 MC per trigger. Breaks even at 2 space events. After 4 events = +16 MC.
reasoning: Excellent rebate card. Space events are among the strongest cards in the game, and this adds pure value to already-good plays. shai_aus (24 upvotes) and benbever both rate it highly. Breaks even after just 2 space events. The heat helps with temperature racing. Works for both engine and rush strategies.
when_to_pick: Early game with space events in hand or planned. Even mid-game it's good if you expect 2+ more space events.

name: Orbital Cleanup
economy: Cost 14+3=17 MC (ti payable) + 2 MC-prod lost (10). Value: 2 VP (10) + Earth+Space tags (3-5) + action: gain MC = science tags. At 4 science tags = 4 MC/gen. Total ~23-31 MC over game.
reasoning: Good science payoff card. With 4+ science tags the action generates meaningful MC, offsetting the -2 MC-prod. The 2 VP is nice. Earth+Space tags enable discounts and ti payment. The -2 MC-prod makes it bad early unless you have strong science engine incoming. No COTD data from key commenters but community rates it as good mid-game science payoff.
when_to_pick: Mid-game with 4+ science tags. The -2 MC-prod means you want it only when the action outweighs the loss.

name: Orbital Reflectors
economy: Cost 26+3=29 MC (ti payable). Value: 2 Venus TR (14.8) + 2 heat-prod (8) + Venus+Space tags (3-5). Total ~26-28 MC. Net ~-1 to -3 MC. Internal anti-synergy.
reasoning: Critically anti-synergistic. Venus pushing is engine-oriented but heat production is rush-oriented. You're paying 29 MC for a card that doesn't coherently support either strategy. shai_aus calls it absolute garbage. Community consensus is D/F tier. The heat production on top of expensive Venus raising is design failure.
when_to_pick: Almost never. Only if Venus is 1-2 steps from the 16% bonus TR and you need the Venus tag for Venuphile.

name: Ore Processor
economy: Cost 13+3=16 MC (steel payable). Action: spend 4 energy for 1 titanium (3 MC) + 1 O2 raise (7-7.4 MC). Net ~4-4.4 MC/action minus 8 MC energy cost. Building tag (1-2).
reasoning: One of the better oxygen bumpers. Costs 4 energy per O2 which is better than Iron/Steelworks ratios, and the titanium bonus adds value. icehawk84 ranks it 2nd best bumper after Steelworks. Niche but powerful against plant-production opponents. With colonies, the energy competition makes it less attractive.
when_to_pick: When you have 4+ energy production and want to deny oxygen to plant players. Not worth setting up specifically for.

name: Outdoor Sports
economy: Cost 8+3=11 MC. Value: 2 MC-prod (10-12) + 1 VP (5). No tags = penalty (-3 to -5). Net ~1-3 MC with penalty. Req: city adjacent to ocean.
reasoning: Sponsors-like card but with no tags (huge penalty), 2 MC more expensive, and a clunky requirement. The 1 VP partially compensates but not enough. shai_aus and Krazyguy75 both rate it poorly. benbever notes in all-expansion play the requirement is rarely met gen 1-2 when you'd want it. Sagitta and Community Services slightly help.
when_to_pick: Only when a city is already adjacent to an ocean AND you're gen 1-2. Very low priority in draft.

name: PR Office
economy: Cost 7+3=10 MC. Value: 1 TR (7-7.4) + 1 MC per Earth tag + Earth tag (2-3). Req: Unity ruling/2 delegates. At 3 Earth tags = 3 MC refund. Net ~0-3 MC.
reasoning: Fairly priced TR with Earth tag refund. At 1 Earth tag (this one), it's 10 MC for 1 TR + 1 MC which is mediocre. With 4+ Earth tags it becomes good value. The Unity party requirement is manageable but limits flexibility. COTD has no key commenter data. A filler Turmoil card.
when_to_pick: With 3+ Earth tags when Unity is ruling. Otherwise skip.

name: Parliament Hall
economy: Cost 8+3=11 MC (steel payable). Value: 1 VP (5) + Building tag (1-2) + 1 MC-prod per 3 building tags. At 6 buildings = 2 MC-prod (10). Total ~16-17. Req: Mars First. Worse Medical Lab.
reasoning: Strictly inferior to Medical Lab: costs 5 MC less but gives 1 MC-prod per 3 tags instead of per 2, has a party requirement, and no science tag. Community consensus is D-tier. The VP makes it playable as a cheap steel dump but the production effect is too weak. benbever notes it's used mainly as a late-game 1VP steel dump.
when_to_pick: As a cheap 1VP steel dump with Mars First ruling. Don't draft for the production effect.

name: Penguins
economy: Cost 7+3=10 MC. Value: 1 VP/animal. At 3 animals = 3 VP (15 MC). At 5 = 5 VP (25 MC). Req: 8 oceans. Animal tag (1-2).
reasoning: Cheapest 1VP animal card with a manageable requirement (8 oceans, usually met gen 5-7 in 3P). Self-generates 3-4 VP over typical game. With animal placement (Large Convoy, Imported Nitrogen) ceiling is higher. shai_aus rates it probably the best 1VP animal for Inventrix. Follows the 1VP-per-animal = B-tier calibration.
when_to_pick: Mid-game when 8 oceans are close. Good animal dump target. With Inventrix playable much earlier.

name: Permafrost Extraction
economy: Cost 8+3=11 MC. Value: 1 ocean (TR 7-7.4 + placement bonus 2-6). Total ~9-13 MC. No tags = penalty (-3 to -5). Req: -8C.
reasoning: Cheap ocean that's 7 MC less than SP, which is good value. But the -8C requirement means it's mid-game at earliest, and no tags means penalty. Risk of oceans being maxed by the time temperature reaches -8C. shai_aus rates it fine with manageable requirement. Better with event rebates (IC, Media Group).
when_to_pick: When temperature is near -8C and oceans remain. Don't speculate early. Good as mid-game free draw.

name: Peroxide Power
economy: Cost 7+3=10 MC (steel payable) + 1 MC-prod lost (5-6). Total ~16 MC gen 1. Value: 2 energy-prod (15) + Power+Building tags (2-3). Total ~17-18 MC. Net ~+1-2.
reasoning: Good energy source when you need it. The -1 MC-prod is less painful than Nuclear Power's -2. Power+Building tags are useful for milestones. shai_aus prefers it over Nuclear Power. Cheap enough to play mid-game. With colonies it's excellent for enabling trading. Not exciting but functional.
when_to_pick: When you need 2 energy production. One of the more efficient energy cards. Good with steel payment.

name: Pets
economy: Cost 10+3=13 MC. Value: 1 VP per 2 animals. With 6-8 cities total = 3-4 VP (15-20 MC). Earth+Animal tags (3-5). Total ~18-25 MC over full game. Pure VP card.
reasoning: Pure VP card that needs early play for maximum value but conflicts with early-game economy needs. In 3P all-expansions, cities are moderate (5-8 total). shai_aus rates it medium -- good in city-heavy games, mediocre otherwise. The 1VP/2 animals ratio is worse than 1VP/1 animal cards. Earth+Animal tags have synergy value. Meat Industry combo is strong.
when_to_pick: When you expect 6+ cities and can play gen 1-2. With Meat Industry it becomes much better. Otherwise low priority.

name: Phobos Space Haven
economy: Cost 25+3=28 MC (ti payable). Value: 3 VP (15) + 1 ti-prod (12.5) + Space+City tags (2-3) + city (no Mars bonuses). Total ~30-31 MC. Net ~+2-3 MC but ti-prod is often wasted late.
reasoning: 3 VP for 28 MC (ti payable) is okay as late-game titanium dump, but the 1 titanium production is wasted if played late. The city isn't on Mars so it doesn't count for most awards/milestones. shai_aus rates it too expensive and bad value. icehawk84 prefers Interstellar Colony Ship. Only play as an endgame titanium dump.
when_to_pick: Last 1-2 gens as titanium dump for 3 VP. Don't play for production -- too slow.

name: Physics Complex
economy: Cost 12+3=15 MC (steel payable). Action: 6 energy -> 2 VP. At 3 uses = 6 VP for 15 + ~18 energy cost = 33 MC total. 5.5 MC/VP. Science+Building tags (4-7).
reasoning: The 'newbie trap' card that looks amazing but is usually mediocre. 6 energy per action is an enormous cost that could be used for temperature/trading. icehawk84 notes it's a scaling late-game card but warns against early play. SoupsBane calculates 4 uses minimum for playability. The Science+Building tags are the best part. Only good with Mass Converter-level energy surplus.
when_to_pick: Only with 6+ energy production and no better use for it. The tags alone can justify it as a steel dump.

name: Pioneer Settlement
economy: Cost 13+3=16 MC + 2 MC-prod lost (10) = ~26 MC total. Value: colony (~13) + 2 VP (10) + Space tag (1-2). Total ~24-25 MC. Net ~-1 to -2 MC. Req: max 1 colony.
reasoning: The worst colony-placing card. The max 1 colony requirement means it can only be played gen 1-2 early, but losing 2 MC-prod early for VP is terrible economy. benbever calculates ~3.5 MC deficit. EspritFort rates it the worst colony card. Standard project colony is strictly better in most cases. Only niche use is late-game titanium dump for 2VP if you somehow still have 0-1 colonies.
when_to_pick: Almost never. Late game with 0-1 colonies and titanium to spend. Even then it's marginal.

name: Plantation
economy: Cost 15+3=18 MC. Value: 1 greenery + O2 TR (7-7.4) + placement bonuses (2-4) + Plant tag (1-2). SP greenery = 23 MC. This saves 5 MC. Total ~10-14 MC.
reasoning: A cheaper standard project greenery (saves 5 MC) with a useful Plant tag. The 2 Science tag requirement is manageable but limits who can play it. Good for NRA enablement and Gardener milestone. ad_hocNC values the plant tag highly. shai_aus calls it fine. No science tag on it means it doesn't feed into science engines.
when_to_pick: When you have 2 science tags and need a greenery or plant tag. Mid-game discount on SP greenery.

name: Political Alliance
economy: Cost 4+3=7 MC. Value: 1 TR (7-7.4). No tags = penalty (-3 to -5). Req: 2 party leaders. Net ~-2 to -5 MC with tag penalty.
reasoning: Cheap TR card that's decent when the requirement is met. No tags is a penalty. benbever rates it good, noting 2 party leaders isn't hard in low player counts. It's a useful event for Legend milestone. shai_aus finds it boring but playable. The Turmoil requirement limits availability. Overall a filler card with narrow upside.
when_to_pick: When you have 2 party leaders and need cheap TR. Good for Legend milestone. Low priority in draft.

name: Potatoes
economy: Cost 2+3=5 MC - 2 plants (~4). Value: 2 MC-prod (10-12) + Plant tag (1-2). Total ~11-14 MC. Net ~+2-5 MC.
reasoning: Extremely cheap plant tag with decent MC production. The cheapest non-prelude plant tag in the game, which shai_aus (27 upvotes) highlights as the key selling point. Losing 2 plants is minor. 2 MC-prod for effective 5-9 MC cost is great early game. Excellent for NRA/Insects enablement. Simple but effective.
when_to_pick: Gen 1-3 when you have 2 plants or can get them easily. The plant tag is the main value. Great cheap production.

name: Power Grid
economy: Cost 18+3=21 MC. No steel/ti payment. Value: energy-prod per Power tag. At 3 tags = 3 energy-prod (22.5). At 2 tags = 2 (15). Power tag (1). Overpriced and circular.
reasoning: Overpriced energy production that can't be discounted by steel/titanium. If you already have enough Power tags to make it efficient, you probably already have enough energy. shai_aus, ad_hocNC, and FieldMouse007 all rate it poorly. The community notes it's likely overcosted by the game designers. Very niche, very situational.
when_to_pick: Almost never. Only with 3+ existing Power tags and desperate need for energy. Thorgate makes it more playable.

name: Power Infrastructure
economy: Cost 4+3=7 MC (steel payable). Action: energy -> MC at 1:1 rate. Energy worth ~1.4 MC used, so losing ~0.4/energy. Power+Building tags (2-3).
reasoning: The action is almost always a bad trade since energy is worth more than MC when used properly (for trading, bumping, heat). The Power+Building tags for 7 MC steel-payable are the real value -- useful for Builder/Diversifier milestones. icehawk84 says he almost exclusively plays it for milestones. One of the weaker cards.
when_to_pick: Only for Builder/Diversifier milestone tags. The action is almost never worth using. Cheap steel dump.
